subject: Negotiation
title: High-Context vs. Low-Context Cultures
description: A short lesson to help you apply High-Context vs. Low-Context Cultures.

hook.text: In Germany, 'no' means no. In Japan, 'that would be difficult' also means no. Miss it and you'll push too far.

buildup.text: Edward Hall divided cultures into high-context (meaning is implied) and low-context (meaning is stated directly).

discovery.text: Low-context negotiators (US, Germany) say what they mean. High-context ones (Japan, Arabia) expect you to read between the lines.

twist.text: Low-context people think high-context people are evasive. High-context people think low-context ones are rude.

climax.text: Neither is wrong. Adapting your communication style to the culture at the table is the real skill.

punchline.text: Listen for what's said. Listen harder for what isn't.

quiz.question: How do high-context cultures typically communicate 'no'?
options: They use indirect phrases like 'that would be difficult'
They walk out of the room
